🔒 Why I’m against the EU “Chat Control” law

The European Commission says this law is about “protecting children.” But let’s be honest: mass surveillance of everyone’s private messages won’t stop traffickers. It will mostly weaken encryption, threaten journalists, whistleblowers, and ordinary citizens — while criminals will just move to other channels.

👉 If protecting children was really the priority, there are better solutions:
	•	Increase the budget of specialized police units, like the OCRTEH in France, which fights child trafficking and sexual exploitation every day on the field. These teams know how to dismantle networks — but they are underfunded and understaffed.
	•	Strengthen international cooperation between Europol, Interpol, and national brigades for minors. Trafficking is cross-border, and so should be the response.
	•	Support victim protection services, like child welfare and NGOs, to ensure children are rescued and protected in the long term.

💡 Real child protection means giving more tools and resources to those who actually hunt down predators — not scanning the private conversations of millions of innocent citizens.

📢 Take action: Learn more and let your voice be heard at stopchatcontrol.eu. and fightchatcontrol.eu, Contact your MEPs and parliamentarians to tell them you oppose this law. Every message counts.

body:
EU member states are once again discussing the introduction of Chat Control—a literal surveillance state nightmare.

Essentially, the Union would mandate every digital service provider with a chat interface, whether it's WhatsApp, Messenger, or others, to scan users' messages before they are sent. This way, countries like Denmark argue, the EU will be better positioned to combat the spread of child sexual abuse material.

It's a noble cause—but the solution is drastic overreach.

Worse still, proponents are using misleading messaging to promote it. For instance, the latest legislative proposal claims the regulation wouldn’t prohibit end-to-end encryption in messaging apps. 

As the cybersecurity expert, Ivan Makatura, tells me, that’s not technically a lie, but it’s fundamentally a bullshit argument. If messages are scanned before they’re encrypted, encryption becomes meaningless.

Chat Control could mark an unprecedented attack on privacy in Europe. It appears to be a broad assault on encryption itself, posing a serious cybersecurity threat, especially when it comes to sensitive information.

The good news? Most of the public—and digital rights activists—still have a strong gag reflex toward mass surveillance. And politicians are starting to reflect that sentiment. Finland, Czechia, and Slovakia backed away from supporting Chat Control.

The legislation still has to go through EU Council negotiations and then a vote in the European Parliament. 
There’s a good chance Chat Control will never come into effect—and that would be a welcome outcome. 
But if this story proves anything, it’s that public outcry can genuinely influence the outcome of an EU legal process. It’s a reminder of how important it is to stand up for your rights.

The latest news saw our danish Justice Minister make poor arguments for Chat Control.
Justice Minister Hummelgaard's arguments for Chat Control sound reasonable until you think about what they actually mean.

So in regard to the danish government's Chat Control Push. Let Me try to explain with simple analogies:
Hummelgaard: "This protects children"
Reality: Imagine saying we need to install cameras in every bedroom to catch child abusers. Real predators would just go to hotels, cars, or other locations without cameras. Meanwhile, every family's privacy is destroyed. That's Chat Control for you. Criminals adapt and innocent families suffer.

Hummelgaard: "We've found a compromise"
Reality: As I explained in a previous discussion on a post by Kaj Grønbæk, this is like installing a door in every house that police can use anytime. Politicians promise they'll only use it "lawfully," but the door is still there. Others will find it too. There's no "compromise" on having secret doors in your home.

Hummelgaard: "This has democratic support"
Reality: Imagine your community voting against mandatory listening devices in every home, but city council installing them anyway because "safety experts" overruled them. That's the kind of surveillance infrastructure the Stasi built in East Germany, though at least they didn't rebrand it as "child protection." Same surveillance, better marketing.

Hummelgaard: "Law enforcement needs this"
Reality: Police solved crimes for decades by getting warrants to search specific houses. Chat Control is like demanding keys to every house "just in case." It's lazy policing that makes everyone less safe.

The Bottom Line:
You wouldn't accept mandatory cameras in your bedroom or government keys to your house. Why accept it for your digital life?

As a Dane, I'm ashamed our country is leading this authoritarian overreach. We're supposed to champion privacy and democracy, not destroy them.
Say no to digital doors for everyone's homes.

body:
🚨 WhatsApp Web Chat Lock Bypass Vulnerability🚨

I recently reported a bypass vulnerability in WhatsApp Web’s Chat Lock to Meta's Bug Bounty. Meta acknowledged it but closed it as “informative”, calling it an accepted risk.

🔒 What is Chat Lock?
Hides chats behind a secret code or biometric lock.

On Whatsapp, hidden chats disappear until the code is entered in search.
If a user forgets the code, WhatsApp forces them to clear locked chats hence deleting chat history unless restored from a backup.

This gives users the impression of strong, cryptographic privacy.

❌ The Vulnerability
Code validation bypass in browser.
With DevTools, the function can be overridden:

d("WAWebChatLockUtils").validateSecretCode = () => Promise.resolve(true);
Any input in the secret code part (even blank) now unlocks chats instantly.

🧪 Proof of Concept (PoC)
Video demo attached bypassing works in seconds.

🔑 Why It Matters
·      False security → Users think chats are protected, but they’re not.
·      Inverted access control → Forgetting the code = permanent loss for the user, but attackers can unlock everything.
·      Forensics blind spot → Tools treat locked chats as encrypted, but Web bypass exposes them.
·      Session hijacking risk → With stolen sessions (cookies/XSS/shared PCs), attackers can reveal, unlock, and interact with chats without the real code.

📩 Meta's Response
“This is an accepted risk… not designed to prevent against sophisticated attackers.”

🤔 Questions for the Community
1)  Should privacy features rely on cryptography & server-side checks, not just JS logic?
2)  Is this truly informative or a critical access control bypass (CWE-602)?
3) How should platforms balance usability vs. real security guarantees?

🧑‍💻 Final Thought
I share this to spark discussion, not criticism. WhatsApp is used by billions; privacy features deserve stronger protection.

👉 Would you classify this as “informative” or a critical flaw?

This editorial by child protection organizations in Denmark repeats the same contradictions present in the Chat Control text. It's very unfortunate that organizations doing important and difficult work would believe blindly in a techno-solutionist proposal that creates enormous risks for very little gain in effectiveness against real child abuse.

The editorial repeats the same mistake that Chat Control does not impact end-to-end encryption. The only argument supporting this claim is that it's written in the proposal. It's such an obvious contradiction that Orwell's doublethink pales in comparison: "This ensures that the detection mechanism can access the data in its unencrypted form for effective analysis and action, without compromising the protection provided by end-to-end encryption once the data is transmitted."

The next argument is that scanning will be "limited" to URLs and visual material, like it is a minor inconvenience. Well, the compromise text admits in Page 2 that text and audio are expected to be included in the future through a review clause. It's always easier to expand the scope of surveillance after the basic infrastructure is in place.

Another fallacy is that "scanning for known assault material is not an untested tool", which conflates widely-deployed scanning of known CSAM in cloud storage (which is easy to bypass) with largely-untested client-side scanning of all communications before they leave a device, which is bound to inundate the authorities with false positives. This is true even under high accuracy rates, just imagine what (a far-from-current) rate of 1% false positives would mean for *all* visual content exchanged daily within the EU. 

Now imagine all the vulnerable people affected by such a broad policy, including not only journalists, immigrants and dissidents when the surveillance machine is built further by authoritarian governments lurking in the EU, but also the very children the proposal is designed to protect. How many of children's pictures or sensitive images exchanged by careless teenagers will end up being inspected manually by the authorities, framing innocents by mistake?

Client-side scanning is textbook mass surveillance. The piece finishes with an evident appeal to emotion, because no one in their right mind would rationally agree that Chat Control is a reasonable and proportional idea.

𝟰𝟬% 𝗼𝗳 𝗔𝗴𝗲𝗻𝘁𝗶𝗰 𝗔𝗜 𝗽𝗿𝗼𝗷𝗲𝗰𝘁𝘀 𝘄𝗶𝗹𝗹 𝗳𝗮𝗶𝗹.
That’s Gartner’s forecast for 2027.

𝗔𝗻𝗱 𝗵𝗼𝗻𝗲𝘀𝘁𝗹𝘆?
That sounds optimistic.

Here’s the mistake I see again and again:
Leaders think agentic AI is just another chatbot. Or that adding a plugin and tweaking prompts is the hard part.

But 𝗮𝗴𝗲𝗻𝘁𝘀 𝗮𝗿𝗲𝗻’𝘁 𝗰𝗵𝗮𝘁.
They don’t just answer - they act.
They run for hours, call APIs, trigger workflows, and complete tasks end-to-end.

And that’s where the real collapse happens.

Because building an agent is easy.
𝗥𝘂𝗻𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗼𝗻𝗲 𝘀𝗮𝗳𝗲𝗹𝘆, 𝗮𝘁 𝘀𝗰𝗮𝗹𝗲, 𝘂𝗻𝗱𝗲𝗿 𝗲𝗻𝘁𝗲𝗿𝗽𝗿𝗶𝘀𝗲 𝗰𝗼𝗺𝗽𝗹𝗶𝗮𝗻𝗰𝗲? 𝗧𝗵𝗮𝘁’𝘀 𝗮 𝘄𝗵𝗼𝗹𝗲 𝗼𝘁𝗵𝗲𝗿 𝗴𝗮𝗺𝗲.

What breaks most projects isn’t model quality.
It’s the missing infrastructure around it:
🔹 𝗡𝗼 𝗼𝗯𝘀𝗲𝗿𝘃𝗮𝗯𝗶𝗹𝗶𝘁𝘆 to trace every step
🔹 𝗡𝗼 𝗽𝗲𝗿𝗺𝗶𝘀𝘀𝗶𝗼𝗻 𝗺𝗼𝗱𝗲𝗹 to control what’s executed
🔹 𝗡𝗼 𝗺𝗲𝗺𝗼𝗿𝘆 𝗺𝗮𝗻𝗮𝗴𝗲𝗺𝗲𝗻𝘁 to decide what’s kept or forgotten

AWS is betting big on this with their new 𝗔𝗴𝗲𝗻𝘁𝗖𝗼𝗿𝗲 stack - long-running workflows, delegated identity, memory vaults, observability, gateways. It’s one attempt to solve the invisible plumbing problem.

The vivid demo? An agent booking a flight through a website - no API, just clicks through like a human, screenshot proof at the end.

That’s not chat. That’s orchestration.

body:
Who is behind the #CHATCONTROL proposal? #US lobby - again. 

"BIRN (Balkan Investigative Reporting Network) investigated who is lobbying and who is the main driver of this controversial proposal back in 2023. As they wrote at the time, behind European Commission Commissioner Ylva Johansson and her proposal to combat online child sexual abuse (CSAM) stands a powerful and well-funded network of lobbyists and associations that, according to internal documents and statements from participants, had undue influence on policies that could change the internet as we know it.

BIRN states that in May 2022, Johansson sent a letter to the American organization Thorn , which was founded in 2012 by Ashton Kutcher and Demi Moore. Thorn is developing AI tools to identify CSAM, and the proposed regulation is designed to combat the spread of this content. In the letter, Johansson invited Thorn's CEO to 'help launch the proposal'. 
...

Although registered as a non-governmental organization, Thorn sells AI tools on the market, so the US Department of Homeland Security bought licenses for $4.3 million.

...

Criticism from the Netherlands
The Dutch organization Offlimits, Europe's oldest child sexual abuse hotline, has openly warned that the EU proposal could turn child protection into a profitable business for tech companies.

- Brussels listens too much to American associations that have their own market interests - said former Offlimits director Marietje Gerkens, adding that Johansson refused to meet with them, while regularly finding time for meetings with representatives of Silicon Valley.

The scientific community is also skeptical. Cryptographer Matthew Green from Johns Hopkins points out that European encryption experts did not participate in the drafting of the proposal, although Europe has them at the world level. In 2023, Apple publicly admitted that attempting CSAM scanning on devices was technically untenable without compromising privacy. Also, research from Imperial College additionally warns that scanning technology on devices could be misused, for example for facial recognition without the user's knowledge.

The proposal is currently in the final stages of the legislative process, with a planned vote in the European Council scheduled for 14 October 2025. According to information from Fight Chat Control, 15 EU Member States support the proposal, while 9 remain undecided and three oppose (Austria, the Netherlands and Poland). The final positions of the Member States are expected to be published on 12 September 2025, and if the proposal is adopted, the next step will be trilateral negotiations between the European Commission, the European Parliament and the Council of the EU to finalise the text of the law. According to some estimates, final adjustments and adoption could take place in late 2025 or early 2026."

Our Discord became something I never expected.

Last week our paid customers asked for a dedicated feedback channel. Within 12 hours of creating it they had:

Self organized into different discussion threads

Started tagging duplicate feature requests to avoid spam

Began filling out bug reports by searching chat history first

Used voting system using reactions to prioritize features

The most surprising part? They're doing quality control for us. New members post requests and existing users reply "already discussed here" with links to previous conversations.

This isn't just community management anymore. Its collaborative product development.

What really hit me was watching a customer spend their time helping another user troubleshoot an issue before escalating to our team. They knew our platform better than some of our beta testers.

The lesson here isnt about Discord specifically. Its about giving your most engaged users ownership over the feedback process.

Most founders treat feedback channels like suggestion boxes. But when you give users agency to organize and prioritize their own requests something magical happens.

They start thinking like product owners instead of complainers.

Now our roadmap planning meetings start with "what are the Discord power users saying" instead of "what do we think users want."

Sometimes the best product decisions come from getting out of your users way.

📊 Control Charts Talk. Are You Listening?

In many organizations, control charts are created, updated, and filed away.
But the truth is — a control chart is more than a graph. It’s your process speaking.

👉 Here’s what it says if you listen carefully:

Within Control Limits: “I’m stable and predictable. Continue monitoring.”

Point Outside Limits: “Something unusual just happened. Investigate!”

Pattern or Trend: “I might be shifting — don’t ignore me.”

Too Much Variation: “Your process isn’t consistent. Look deeper.”

A control chart helps separate signal from noise. Instead of reacting to every small up and down, it teaches us to respond only when the process is truly calling for action.

🎯 This is why control charts are the backbone of Statistical Process Control (SPC). They prevent overreaction, reduce firefighting, and promote a culture of data-driven decision making.

So next time you see a control chart, pause for a moment.
It’s not just lines and dots… it’s your process talking.
The question is: Are you listening?

I always wanted a way to restart ChatGPT with the same knowledge, but cleaner. That wish just came true.

I was using ChatGPT a lot for my everyday coding and brainstorming. Over time, as the chat grew longer, ChatGPT became sharper, until it started to hallucinate. I’d often think: “I wish I could start a new chat with the same history and context but avoid the drift.” Well, OpenAI just made that a reality with their “branching” feature.

Here’s how it works: simply hover over any ChatGPT message, open the three-dot menu under the reply, and select “Branch in new chat.” It creates a parallel thread from that exact point, keeping context, separating paths, and preserving the original all at once.

Why this matters:
- Safe experimentation: You can explore alternate logic or brainstorm fresh variations without disrupting your main conversation.
- Cleaner context control: No more lengthy chats bloated with irrelevant detours, each branch stays on point.
- Reduced hallucination risk: By cleanly restarting from a known state, you avoid compounding errors that snowball over long threads. It’s not a fix for hallucinations, but a powerful way to manage context effectively.

body:
Small business owners, let’s talk AI.

We’ve all been there, using AI at “Level 1”: email drafts, quick summaries, proofreading. It’s helpful, saves time, and lets us maneuver faster with fewer people.

I even used it to organize my thoughts for this post. But here’s the question we often skip over:

👉 Are we being strategic, or just scratching the surface?
👉 Are we looking at the risks as much as the rewards?

Not every business can hire a Chief AI Officer (CAIO), but that doesn’t mean you can’t apply the same principles in your own way. Start here:

1️⃣ Clean Data – AI is only as good as what you feed it. Protect client and business data by:

▪︎Anonymizing names/emails before pasting into AI
•Turning off Chat History in ChatGPT (Settings → Data Controls) so your chats aren’t used for training
•Keeping sensitive details in-house, and only sharing patterns or summaries with AI


2️⃣ AI Guardrails – Boundaries matter. AI should never run unchecked in your business. Think about:

Access levels: Who on your team is allowed to use AI for what?

•Compliance: Make sure AI outputs align with laws in your industry (privacy, HR, financial reporting).
•Bias & brand voice: Review outputs critically, does it represent your business fairly, ethically, and in your tone?
•Decision check: AI should support decisions, not make them for you. Keep a human in the loop.


3️⃣ Clear Strategy – Without a plan, AI becomes a shiny distraction. Anchor it in outcomes:

•Revenue: Is this AI use driving sales, upsells, or new market opportunities?
•Cost savings: Does it reduce workload, eliminate duplicate systems, or improve efficiency?
•Customer experience: Is it improving response time, personalization, or service quality?
•Competitive edge: Will this use of AI differentiate you in a crowded market?

AI can either be a growth engine or a cost sink, it depends on how intentional you are.

Thank you Matthew Rottman for his article and great tips. 

What level are you currently using AI at in your business? Do you have a plan to move beyond "level 1"

- Messages are processed privately and anonymously

- AI only sees what’s in your input box, not your full chat

Hi network, It’s been a while ;)

I’ve just wrapped up a 14-month industrial placement at J.P. Morgan Chase as a Software Engineer, and what a journey it’s been!

When I first joined, I wasn’t sure if Software Engineering was for me. I chose Computer Science relatively late and didn’t have the portfolio of side projects that many of my classmates did.

But slowly and surely, I found my rhythm. I was building real software used by real people (for real). I worked with Python and React, contributing to tools that support resiliency, controls, and testing in the firm’s largest trade management system. And if there’s one thing I’ve learnt working in an investment bank, it’s that stability is key 🔑

Supporting clients, building features, fixing bugs: I realized this is exactly what I love to do. 

Here are 3 big takeaways from my experience (and maybe something useful for you too):

1. Don’t be afraid to ask questions
Many people told me this when I started, but I thought surely I should prove my independence 🤔. However, my curiosity over time is what helped me understand the complex eco-system around me, and how my work fits into that picture, further enhancing my business results. 

2. Teamwork makes the dream work
Everyone brings something different to the table. When working on urgent production issues, the collaboration and camaraderie was essential in making those dreadful problems go away! And you learn a great deal by coding with someone else. 

3. Be yourself ✨
I was lucky to be part of a diverse and very supportive team. I didn’t have to fit into a rigid box of what I thought an intern should be. My motto: be friendly, open, curious, hardworking, and good opportunities will follow. That’s also what will make your contributions unique in every part of the process ;)

Finally, I want to say a huge thank you to Sam Raddon my manager, my amazing team, and the intern cohort: you all made this experience so special. I learned more than I ever expected, and I genuinely enjoyed every team dinner, intern social, and coffee chat ⭐️

It’s been another crazy week in AI 👀

— Nvidia reports $46.7B revenue, fueled by AI
 — Anthropic raises $13B at $183B valuation
 — OpenAI buys Statsig for $1.1B, Raji named CTO
 — Microsoft launches two in-house models
 — Meta reorganizes and pushes new Llama
 — xAI drops Grok Code Fast 1
 — Meta’s AI hiring spree backfires
 — Alibaba unveils domestic AI chip
 — Anthropic builds Claude Code for web
 — Mistral adds memory to Le Chat

Here’s everything you need to know:


1/ Nvidia, the world’s most valuable company, reported $46.7B in revenue this quarter, up 56% YoY. AI data center sales drove the surge.

2/ Anthropic raised $13B at a $183B valuation, tripling since March. ARR jumped from $1B to $5B, with Claude Code surpassing $500M run-rate.

3/ OpenAI acquired Statsig for $1.1B, bringing in cofounder Vijay Raji as CTO of applications. The move strengthens its experimentation stack as ChatGPT scales.

4/ Microsoft unveiled two in-house models: MAI-Voice-1, generating speech in under a second, and MAI-1-preview, a MoE model trained on ~15k H100s. It’s a bid to reduce reliance on OpenAI.

5/ Meta will release Llama 4.X before year-end, its first project from the new Superintelligence Labs. The unit now splits into training, research, product, and infra.

6/ xAI launched Grok Code Fast 1, a coding model priced at $0.20 per million tokens vs $18+ from rivals. It’s free for now via GitHub Copilot and Cursor.

7/ Meta’s AI hiring spree is unraveling: ChatGPT co-creator Shengjia Zhao nearly quit days after joining, while other OpenAI recruits lasted under a month.

8/ Alibaba revealed a domestic AI inference chip under pressure from Beijing to cut Nvidia reliance. It’s still in testing.

9/ Anthropic is building a web version of Claude Code with GitHub integration and safe sandboxes. No release date yet.

10/ Mistral gave Le Chat “Memories” with transparent recall, citations, and editable logs. It’s designed for more user control.

You can walk into a room with the best ideas —
But if your energy is off, no one’s listening.

Here’s the truth:

→ People don’t just hear your words.
→ They feel your presence.

You don’t control the mood of the entire workplace.
But you do control how people feel after interacting with you.

If you bring pressure, stress and negativity — that spreads.
If you bring calm, support and clarity — that spreads too.

Here’s how to “bring the sunshine”, regardless of the forecast:

Smile when you enter a call
↳ Simple. But powerful.

Don’t start every chat with urgency
↳ “Got a second?” > “We need to talk.”

Check in with people without needing anything
↳ “Just wanted to say hi. How are you?”

Protect your tone in emails and Slack
↳ Clarity without coldness = connection.

Be warm, even when others aren’t
↳ Kindness is a leadership decision, not a reaction.

Pressure is contagious.
So is kindness.
